page.title: 19Marnhull-Hardy's Marlott.
page.content: Hardy presents Marlott in the Vale of Blackmoor as a'long and broken village'.It remains so,with The Crown (Pure Drop) readily identified at its main crossroads. Marlott's life revolved around the farming year and the Church:the new National School added an extra dimension.Tess passed the Sixth Standard.The parental cottage,(like many demolished)was thatched,gabled, with flag-stone floors and outhouse, and held for three lives until the death of Tess's father,reduced to a haggler and frequenter of Rolliver's, 'the single ale house at this end of the village'. He rented an allotment,' two hundred yards out of the village'. Marlott's influences have important bearings on later decisions and circumstantial developments in the tragedy of Tess.
